entities: Special Representative of the Secretary-General for Children and Armed Conflict
summary:
The Security Council,
Reaffirming previous resolutions on children in armed conflict, calls for 
implementation of international norms for their protection; 
Supports Secretary-General's call for "an era of application" of these norms; 
Encourages UN agencies to strengthen cooperation on child protection; 
Demands parties to conflict stop recruiting or using children, and 
supports dialogue to develop action plans to end this practice; 
Notes with concern the list of parties violating children's rights, 
and may take steps if insufficient progress is made; 
Urges States to control illicit trade of small arms to parties not respecting children's rights; 
Calls on States to respect humanitarian law on child protection; 
Reiterates its determination to include child protection in UN peacekeeping mandates; 
Notes with concern cases of sexual exploitation and abuse, 
and requests countries to incorporate core principles into codes of conduct.
Here is a summarized version of the document:

The Security Council:
11. Requests UN agencies to provide HIV/AIDS education, testing, and counselling services to all UN peacekeepers, police, and humanitarian personnel.

12. Calls for the protection, rights, and well-being of children to be integrated into peace processes, agreements, and post-conflict recovery.

13. Urges parties to involve children affected by armed conflict in disarmament, demobilization, and reintegration processes, considering girls' specific needs.

14. Calls on parties to abide by commitments made to the Special Representative of the Secretary-General for Children and Armed Conflict.

15. Requests the Secretary-General to include child protection in all country-specific reports to the Security Council.

16. Requests the Secretary-General to submit a report by 31 October 2003 on:
    (a) Progress made by parties to end recruitment or use of children in armed conflict.
    (b) Assessment of child rights violations and abuses.
    (c) Proposals for effective monitoring and reporting.
    (d) Best practices on integrating child needs into disarmament, demobilization, rehabilitation, and reintegration programmes.

17. Decides to remain actively seized of this matter.
